title: How to Get Concealer Out of Clothes

steps.title: Scrape any excess concealer from the clothes with a knife or spoon.
steps.content: Scrape any excess concealer from the clothes with a knife or spoon. Be gentle as you scoop or scrape the fabric. You don’t want to rub the concealer into the clothes, only remove any extra that is sitting on top. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Apply a stain remover and dab the stain with a clean wet cloth.
steps.content: Apply a stain remover and dab the stain with a clean wet cloth. You can find stain removing sprays or pocket-sized stain removing pens in the laundry aisle. Grab whichever type you have on hand and apply it to the stain. Dab it with a clean wet cloth to help it absorb into the stain. [2] X Research source You can also dab a bit of ammonia on the stain if you don’t have a stain remover handy.

steps.title: Add a second coat of stain remover and let it sit for at least 10 minutes.
steps.content: Add a second coat of stain remover and let it sit for at least 10 minutes. If the stain doesn’t significantly fade after the first application of stain remover, apply another layer on the stain. Don’t dab this time. Instead, let it sit and soak in by itself for about 10 minutes. [3] X Research source The stain should be at least 80% gone before you put it in the washing machine, otherwise it may not come out.

steps.title: Rinse the stain and soak in hot water if you are short on time.
steps.content: Rinse the stain and soak in hot water if you are short on time. If you don’t have a stain remover handy, or you don’t have time to apply it, simply rinse the stain as thoroughly as possible with cold water. Then, let it soak in hot water in the sink. Put it in the washing machine when you are able. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Wash the garment in a washing machine with cold or warm water.
steps.content: Wash the garment in a washing machine with cold or warm water. If the water temperature is above 75 °F (24 °C), your laundry detergent will become less effective, and excessive heat can also help set stains in your clothes. Be sure to check the care tag on your clothing to choose the optimal setting. [5] X Research source It’s usually fine to wash cotton with cold water and the regular wash setting. Fabrics made from polyester should be washed with warm water on the permanent press cycle to reduce wrinkles .

steps.title: Avoid using the dryer until the stain is completely gone.
steps.content: Avoid using the dryer until the stain is completely gone. It’s best to let the garment air dry. The heat from the dryer can permanently set the stain. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Use an ammonia solution as a last-ditch effort to salvage a set stain.
steps.content: Use an ammonia solution as a last-ditch effort to salvage a set stain. If you didn’t notice your stain before washing and drying it, it’s probably already set. If nothing else works to loosen the stain, try combining 1 quart 1 US quart (950 ml) hot water, 1 tablespoon (15 ml) household ammonia, and 1 ⁄ 2 teaspoon (2.5 ml) bleach-free liquid laundry detergent. Soak the stain in the solution for 20 minutes, then rinse and launder. [7] X Research source You can also use a toothbrush to scrub the ammonia solution into the stain before laundering. Never combine ammonia with bleach, since the combination can result in toxic fumes. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Mix 1 US tbsp (15 ml) dishwashing detergent with 2 c (470 ml) cool water.
steps.content: Mix 1 US tbsp (15 ml) dishwashing detergent with 2 c (470 ml) cool water. Grab your dishwashing liquid and add 1 US tbsp (15 ml) to 2 c (470 ml) of cool water in a bowl. Make sure the water is very cool, as this will help lift out the stain. [9] X Research source If you don’t have liquid detergent, you can use any gentle soap in a pinch, including shampoo, hand soap, or body wash. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Dab the stain with the detergent solution.
steps.content: Dab the stain with the detergent solution. Dip a clean cloth into the detergent solution and dab the stain with it. Make sure the stain is fully saturated. Don’t rub or you might spread the stain. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Blot the area with a clean towel and repeat until the stain disappears.
steps.content: Blot the area with a clean towel and repeat until the stain disappears. Take a clean towel and gently blot the area dry. If the stain is still there, repeat the above steps, applying the detergent, blotting, and drying the area. [12] X Research source You can repeat this step as many times as needed until the stain disappears completely.

steps.title: Remove the detergent solution from the garment with cold water.
steps.content: Remove the detergent solution from the garment with cold water. After the stain disappears, soak a sponge in cool water. Dab and gently rub the sponge on the area to remove the detergent solution from the stain. Let the area air dry. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Get rid of the concealer with shaving cream.
steps.content: Get rid of the concealer with shaving cream. After you’ve removed any excess concealer from the fabric with a knife or spoon, apply a generous amount of shaving cream to the stain. Rub and scrub the shaving cream into the stain. Rinse and repeat until all the concealer is gone. [14] X Research source Be patient and rub the shaving cream into the fabric well. It may not be the quickest method, but it is effective.

steps.title: Use a makeup wipe to remove concealer stains like the pros.
steps.content: Use a makeup wipe to remove concealer stains like the pros. Using a makeup wipe on clothes is an old trick used by makeup artists at fashion shows. Just gently blot the stain with the makeup wipe until it fades away. [15] X Research source This is most effective on a very fresh stain, so grab that makeup wipe immediately before the stain dries or sets. Makeup wipes work best on cotton fabrics. Be sure to spot test a small, indiscreet area if you want to try it on more delicate fabrics like silk.

steps.title: Apply an ice cube to lift out the stain.
steps.content: Apply an ice cube to lift out the stain. Rub an ice cube on the stain vigorously until it fades away. The coldness can help to lift the stain, while hot water can sometimes actually spread it. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Add a small splash of rubbing alcohol if the stain is stubborn.
steps.content: Add a small splash of rubbing alcohol if the stain is stubborn. If you are having trouble removing the stain with a water-based stain removing product, try adding a splash of alcohol to the area. This can help loosen the stain even more. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Try using a dry cleaning solvent to remove the stain.
steps.content: Try using a dry cleaning solvent to remove the stain. Dampen a clean white cloth with dry cleaning solvent, which you can find in the laundry aisle or online. Dab the solvent on the stain and blot until the solvent is absorbed. Repeat these steps until the stain is completely gone and then let the garment air dry. [18] X Research source Dry cleaning solvents work to remove stains without water, so once you see the stain is gone, don’t rinse it with water.
